so much brought that with me I'm in this

to behave myself as I walked among these
white coated researchers hunched over
their chemistry sets and conveyor belts
and not in some top-secret munitions lab
I met Kellogg's in Battle Creek Michigan
and I'm not there to help them engineer
some new cracker or taste a new cereal
I'm there because of salt I'm a
journalist just starting a new book on
processed foods and overnight it seemed
suddenly salt has become this gigantic
evil especially the amounts of salt in
processed foods high blood pressure
heart disease obesity salt has become
the number one public menace and for me
I'm like really torn by that because
after fat salt is my go-to craving I
actually secretly once built an entire
family vacation around visiting a
factory of the route 11 potato chip
company in the Shenandoah Valley and
those free samples were heaven so I send
enough to Kellogg's and some of the
other food giants and I said hey guys
like what's up with all the salt you're
using and surprisingly Kellis got back
to me and said hey coming in we'll talk
to you well he did a lot more than talk
I was met at the entrance by the chief
technical officer who's in charge of all
things scientific and by the chief
spokeswoman who's in charge of all
things public image and as we're walking
through the factory laboratory floor the
first thing that hits me is this one of
a kind
and sweet right out of childhood sent
somebody somewhere in there is cooking

a ten-year-old latchkey kid with

strawberry pop-tarts but then comes the

officer goes hey Michael I've had some

without salt and we start with the
normal cheez-its which frankly I could

salt this one's and we can't even
swallow them they stick to the roofs of
our mouths
because as chief technical officer
explains salt provides texture and
solubility next we move to the frozen
Eggo waffles put them in a toaster and
the saltless ones come out looking and

chief technical officer provides color
and taste and finally we turn to the

that's a milk take a big spoonful and
before I can say anything the chief

thinking really salt that rock that

point I'm thinking I don't think they
brought me here with evil intentions to
give me this lesson in salt and in fact
I don't see the processed food industry
as this evil empire that intentionally
set out to make us hugely overweight or
otherwise ill these are companies doing
what all companies want to do which is
to make as much money as possible by

these scientists here are baring their
souls to me about how for them making
money means using gobs of salt to make

utterly irresistible but for me this is
like a journalists nightmare
because I leave Kellogg's and I'm
thinking my heart is like going mushy
because I'm thinking these guys are like
really screwed I mean they can take a
little bit of salt out of their products
but take too much and they're gonna mess
they're gonna lose some of that huge
iconic flavor that makes these products

know even pop-tarts need salt
I mean pop-tarts without salt is like

privately when they're talking to each

the outside the first thing that touches
your tongue dissolves in the saliva hits

that keep eating and I'm forgetting that
I'm going here but what about all the

this
scientists themselves make up for it by

forget about it but salt is different
the resident expert explained to me
we're not even born
liking salt and it gets out these

there's nothing like baby pictures to

are much more apt than kids who are fed

about that time in a pizzeria
but more importantly for me and the book
what that meant was that when it came to
salt the industry wasn't just exploiting
our biology it was training us to like
salt it was creating a biology it was
creating this idea in us that we needed
lots and lots of salt and for me this is
a moment of truth I'm getting up there
in years and that doctor hasn't called

pressure but here is my strategy I have
